Title: Barbara Stanwyck with director Anatole Litvak in Sorry, Wrong Number
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: That feels good... In the suspense story about a neurotic woman who overhears her own murder being plotted on crossed telephone lines, the star was alone before the camera for 12 consecutive days, playing highly dramatic scenes which were mentally and physically exhausting. Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Barbara Stanwyck being hooked up to an electro-cardiograph apparatus in Sorry, Wrong Number
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Barbara Stanwyck gave the most realistic performance of her long Hollywood career during the filming of a hospital scene in Hal Wallis' "Sorry, Wrong Number." In the suspense movie based on the famous radio thriller she plays the neurotic wife (of Burt Lancaster) who over hears her own murder being plotted on the telephone. For the scene in which her heart is tested to determine if anything is organically wrong, director Anatole Litvak used a real electro-cardiograph machine and trained operators. When the camera stopped turning an actual graph of the star's heart beats had been recorded in red ink on the paper chart. Here is what happened when the true-to-fact scene was filmed. 1. A technician takes a pulse count of Barbara Stanwyck before the electro-cardiograph apparatus is attached. Miss S. passes O.K. and says "Let's go, boys." [Stamped] Photo By, Mal. Bulloch

For the sake of expertness and to keep its audiences pinned on seat-edge, its principal roles are played by CHARLES LAUGHTON and BORIS KARLOFF, old hands at this sort of thing. SALLY FORREST and RICHARD STAPLEY are starred in romantic roles. Screenplay is by Jerry Sackheim, direction by Joseph Pevney, production by Ted Richmond for Universal-International. Enroute Alan shows them a giant water wheel which, when thrown into gear, moves the wall of the cell wherein Blanche's father is prisoner. Blanche meets her father for the first time and is placed in the cell with him and her bridegroom - to be crushed to death!

Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:PRIZE STILL FROM A PRIZE COMEDY, "TIGHT LITTLE ISLAND""Tight Little Island," one of the rarest of comedies to come from England, concludes with this romantic and artistically delightful scene showing an Army sergeant following his bride into the sand dunes. The players are Bruce Seton and Joan Greenwood who, with Basil Radford, James Robertson Justice and a large cast, enact a highly original screenplay which should prove one of the "sleepers" of the new year. The film is a J. Arthur Rank presentation.

Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: HOLLYWOOD GOES SCIENTIFIC - Every new ailment is followed by a remedy, even in Hollywood, where time is money and ailments are costly. Newest scientific discovery in the film capitol is the lubrication of inflamed vocal cords in the throats of singers. Here, Martha Raye is shown on the set of Paramount's "Tropic Holiday," having a new oil formula injected into her vocal cords by Dr. Edward T. Fogel, throat specialist who perfected the treatment. The soothing effect of the injection lasts two hours, during which Martha is able to sing her "hottest" songs, and production is not delayed. All Hollywood is to follow suit, in cases of throat difficulties.

Title: Dana Andrews, Benny Baker, George Mathews, and Danny Kaye in Up In Arms
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:SF-29 and 26.TROUBLE IN THE BARRACKS -- Danny Kaye, as a new recruit in the Army, is at the mercy of Benny Baker and George Mathews, his tough sergeant, but Dana Andrews is coming up in the rear to intercede in the scene from Samuel Goldwyn's "Up In Arms," Technicolor comedy with music. Danny, starring as a comic hypochondriac in the picture, is striggling [sp] against drinking a concoction that has been mixed up from his various and sundry medicines. It is punishment for playing the sergeant's victrola without permission. Danny Kaye, the noted Broadway comedian, makes his screen debut in the offering which also introduces Constance Dowling, of the New York stage, and features Dinah Shore. Elliott Nugent directs.
